STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
April 22, 2022
Susan Humeau
Samaritas - Southwest
4341 S Westnedge ST 2000
Kalamazoo, MI 49008
RE: License #: CB390258392
Samaritas - Southwest
4341 S Westnedge ST 2000
Kalamazoo, MI 49008
Dear Ms. Humeau:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
4/11/22-4/22/22. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It
should be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of
the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of
this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 200
121 Franklin Street SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49507
(269) 330-7082
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT

License #: CB390258392
Licensee Name: Samaritas
Licensee Address: 8131 East Jefferson Avenue
Detroit, MI 48214-2691
Licensee Telephone #: (231) 936-1012

Name of Facility: Samaritas - Southwest
Facility Address: 4341 S Westnedge ST 2000
Kalamazoo, MI 49008
Facility Telephone #: (269) 345-5776
Original Issuance Date: 12/09/2003

SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
PA 116 - Confidentiality
722.120(3)
A licensee shall keep the records the department prescribes
regarding each child in its control and care and shall report to the
department, when requested, the facts the department requires
with reference to the children upon forms furnished by the
department. Except as otherwise provided in this subsection and
subsection (4), records regarding children and facts compiled
about children and their parents and relatives are confidential and
disclosure of this information shall be properly safeguarded by the
childcare organization, the department, and any other entity in
possession of the information.
1 of 3 Special Evaluation Reports reviewed identified the involvement of CPS.
R 400.12325 License recommendation.
(4) Except for an original license, an agency shall recommend to
the department the issuance of a provisional license only when
both of the following conditions exist:
(a) The agency complies with subrule (3)(a) and (b) of this
rule.
1 of 6 open foster home files reviewed documented that emergency procedures
were not practiced as required; however, no CAP was developed.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(f) Documentation that the foster parent has received
orientation to the policies of the borrowing agency.
2 of 3 borrowed bed files reviewed did not contain the required documentation
regarding orientation.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
4

(a) Submit a special investigation record to the department's
licensing authority within 5 working days in the manner
prescribed by the department.
1 of 3 Special Evaluations reviewed contained documentation that the Special
Investigation Record (259) was not provided to the department within the required
timeframe.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information:
3 of 3 Special Evaluation Reports reviewed were not completed within 15 days of the
conclusion of the evaluation/verbal review of findings with the foster family.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child's
record before a change of placement occurs:
(g) Information about the child was shared with the new
placement, consistent with the requirements of R 400.12417.
2 of 8 open foster care reviewed were missing documentation that the new caregiver
was provided all required information prior to a youth's replacement.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
1 of 4 open IL files reviewed contained an ISP that was not completed timely.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 4/17/2020, CAP approved 5/7/2020
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
5

3 of 8 open foster care case files reviewed contained service plans that were not
completed within the required timeframe.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 4/17/2020, CAP approved 5/7/2020
Interim 4/19/2021, CAP approved 5/14/2021
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is incompliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-06B FAMILY TEAM MEETING
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case Plan (ISP)
- within 30 calendar days before the case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three business days
prior to a planned change of placement or no later than three
business days after an unplanned placement change.
Case Closure Within 30 calendar days before the case closure
date or one business day after unplanned court ordered
dismissal.
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, is
used to capture family demographics, FTM logistical
information, needs, strengths, action steps, safety concerns and
the safety plan, and any recommendations made for the family
during the FTM. The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be
completed for every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink within 7 business days of the FTM.
6

9 of 12 open case files reviewed (8 foster care, 4 IL) did not contain documentation
that all required FTMs were held as required and/or the required signed documents
were not present.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED previously cited as 722-09C
Renewal 4/17/2020, CAP approved 5/7/2020
Interim 4/19/2021, CAP approved 5/14/2021
SIR 2022C0444005 2/28/2022, CAP approved 4/6/2022
FOM 722-06J RIGHTS OF CHILDREN IN FOSTER CARE
Within 30 calendar days of removal, the caseworker must review
and explain the DHS-5307, Rights and Responsibilities for
Children and Youth in Foster Care, and the agency's grievance
policy with the child, foster parents, caregivers, and parents. The
caseworker must be prepared to answer any questions the child,
parents, and caregivers may have.
After the document is reviewed the signatures of the child and
caseworker must be obtained. The parent or caregiver must sign
on behalf of the child, if the child is younger than 11 years old or is
unable to sign the document. The caseworker must complete the
information on the last page of the document with the applicable
contact information and provide all participants with a signed copy
and upload a copy to MiSACWIS.
Placement Change When a child under age 11 or who is
otherwise unable to sign the DHS-5307 changes placement, the
caseworker must review the DHS-5307 and the agency's
grievance policy with the new caregiver and obtain their
signature on the DHS-5307 within 30 days of the placement
change.
Documentation The DHS-5307 must be reviewed and re-
signed annually. The caseworker must document the review in
the social work contacts, and the caseworker must upload the
DHS-5307 to the Documents hyperlink in MiSACWIS.
1 of 8 open care case files reviewed did not contain documentation that the
caregiver signed the 5307 within 30 days placement.
FOM 722-08A ONGOING CASE SERVICE PLANS - AGENCY SIGNATURES
Prior to finalizing, the caseworker and supervisor must review
the case service plan and all linked assessments and treatment
plans during a face-to-face meeting. Case service plan review
may occur during monthly case consultation (supervision).
7

The supervisor must review and approve the service plan within
14 calendar days of the report date.
4 of 12 open case files reviewed (8 foster care, 4 IL) contained reports that were
approved outside of the 14-day requirement.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED previously cited as 722-09
Renewal 4/17/2020, CAP approved 5/7/2020
Interim 4/19/2021, CAP approved 5/14/2021
FOM 722-08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND SIGNATURES
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable:
 Caseworker
 Supervisor
 Second line supervisor, when siblings in care are placed
apart
 Parents who are a member of a participating household.
 Youth ages 14 and older.
 Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court-
ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must check yes
or no for the following when signing the treatment plan:
 I have participated in the development of the Case
Service Plan and the Parent Agency Treatment Plan.
 I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent Agency
Treatment Plan.
 I have been provided a copy of the Case Service Plan
and Parent Agency Treatment Plan to review, and I will
have the opportunity to express my disagreement with
the Case Service Plan and Parent Agency Treatment
Plan when the information is presented to court.
Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to sign the
treatment plan, the caseworker must identify and document
actions needed to secure the parent’s and/or youth’s
participation in service planning and compliance with the
treatment plan. The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signatures pages into the
electronic case record within 30 days of the report date.
8

6 of 12 open case files reviewed (8 foster care, 4 IL) did not contain all required
signatures obtained as required. The missing/late signatures, include worker,
supervisor, caregiver, and parent signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED previously cited as 722-08C
Renewal 4/17/2020, CAP approved 5/7/2020
Interim 4/19/2021, CAP approved 5/14/2021
FOM 722-08E FOSTER CARE/JUVENILE JUSTICE ACTION SUMMARY
The DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary is
used to document specific administrative actions or changes in
a case, including: • Child fatality. • Change in caseworker or
organization. • Change in parent contact information. • Foster
care transfer to adoption. • Change in placement. • Temporary
break from placement. • Program or case closing.
COMPLETION REQUIREMENTS The caseworker must
complete the DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action
Summary and upload to MiSACWIS within the timeframe
required for the specified action/change.
Placement Change - Prior to a planned placement change, or
within three business days of an emergency placement change.
Foster Care/ Juvenile Justice Program/Case Closure -
Within three business days of foster care and/or juvenile justice
program/case closure.
Caseworker/ Organization Change - Within three business
days of change in caseworker and/or organization.
11 of 21 cases reviewed (12 open, 9 closed) did not have all action summaries
completed within the required timeframes present.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
SIR 2022C0444005 2/28/2022, CAP approved 4/6/2022
FOM 722-16 YOUNG ADULT VOLUNTARY FOSTER CARE
The DHS-1295, Young Adult Monthly Visit Report, must be
completed with the youth during each home visit. A copy must
be uploaded into MiSACWIS a copy must be given to the youth.
1 of 2 open files of YAVFC youth reviewed was missing required 1295 forms.
9

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 SER’s must be based on the licensing investigation and not include interviews
completed by other investigators, unless the licensing worker was present
and participated.
 When adjustments are made to foster home water temperature, the newly
verified temperature must be documented.
 Dates emergency procedures are practiced are required within foster home
studies. Indicating “quarterly” or the month completed is not sufficient.
 Official transcripts are required to be in each personnel file.
 When PATP signatures are secured from parents/caregivers/youth, the
worker and supervisor signature must be present and dated.
V. CONSULTATION
 Verify accurate dates are being documented in SER’s regarding allegation
intake and initiation.
 PATPs should only be mailed for signatures when necessary and should not
be a standard practice.
 Ensure reports being signed and uploaded are not in “draft” mode.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted three acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
SIR 2022C0444005 3/1/2022, CAP approved 4/6/2022
 The agency is not in compliance with all areas of the CAP as evidenced by
repeat violations documented within this report
SIR 2022C0112008, CAP approved 4/20/2022
 This CAP was approved 2 days prior to the completion of this report;
therefore, there has not been time to implement and evaluate the CAPs
effectiveness.
Interim 4/19/2021 3/24/2022, CAP approved 5/14/2021
 There are multiple areas in which the agency is not in compliance with this
CAP due to repeat violations documented within this report. The repeat
citations and lack of CAP effectiveness is partially attributed to a nearly 100%
turnover rate in staff and supervisors.
10

Chief Administrator Assessment – The Chief administrator demonstrated an
awareness of the challenges maintaining adherence to agency’s previous CAP as
well as achieving licensing compliance and attributed this in part to the high staffing
turnover rate. The chief administrator identified the need to retrain staff of the CAP
and internal procedures needed to improve compliance.
Interviews – The agency staff and supervisors interviewed did not report any
concerns and indicated that they feel they currently have a stable and dedicated
team.
VII. DCWL Analyst Concerns
No safety concerns identified.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
April 22, 2022
________________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
April 22, 2022
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
11
